titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0947, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Gospel lectionary in Greek. Includes both Synaxarion and Menologion. Lection headings and Ammonian section numbers. Restoration of text (paper, 15th century) from lost parchment leaves. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 45.

Quarter-page miniatures number 4, and include portraits of the Evangelists Mark and Matthew, of St. Simeon Stylites the Elder and his mother the Venerable Martha, and of the Christ Child's Presentation in the temple.

headpieces.p: Headpieces of interlace, scrollwork, and geometric patterns in green, brown, and light red (fols. 54r, 112r, 133v, 151v, 152r). Horizontal bars of similar design occur at minor divisions of the text.

initials.p: Major initials of green, brown, light red, and purple (45-80 mm) set off from text and embellished with foliate, bead, geometric, and knot motifs. Inhabited initial of serpents (fol. 167v). Minor initials set off from the text in red.

watermarks.p: Watermarks of inserted leaves similar to Briquet, Coupe 4540 (Vicence, 1476), and Fleur 6689 (Udine, 1448).

physDesc.extent: 207 leaves, of which 58 are replacement leaves of paper.

foliation.p: 52 (foliated paper replacement leaves) + 144 + 6 (foliated paper replacement leaves) + 5. Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil 1-207.

collation.p: 19 parchment quires, and 8 paper quires, each of 8 leaves, with the exception of quire 7 of 4 leaves, quires 10 and 11, respectively of 9 and 7 leaves, quire 26 of 6 leaves, and quire 27 of 5 leaves. Estimate of content lost: Johannine section for Weekdays, Saturdays, and Sundays; Matthean section for Saturdays, and Sundays; leaves from quire 27 (after fol. 207, various lections). Missing text of fols. 1-52 restored on inserted paper leaves in the 15th century including the Heothina portion (fols. 197r-202v), though the text was extant on parchment (fols. 196v, 203r-207r).
Quire numbers from fol. 53r on the first leaf of each parchment quire (recto, lower center), 8-25, 27 (η-κε, κζ). Paper quires numbered 1-7 and 26 (α-ζ, κϛ).

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 165 x 125 mm (fol. 62r). Each column is 165 x 55 mm with a space of 15 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 25 lines. Ruling with hard point. Pricking in the outer margins.

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in medium brown ink.
Punctuation includes high and low points, comma, marks of interrogation and elision. Cross for full stop. Quotation marks in left margin next to each line of quoted text.
Occasional corrections to the text added in the margins and noted with reference marks.

condition.p: Holes in several parchment leaves. Hinges used to reinforce a number of quires. Insect damage to some inserted paper leaves. Minor dirt and water stains.

binding.p: Bound in thin black leather over boards. Spine mended with brown velvet.

origin.p: The manuscript is judged to have been written in Albania, or Southern Italy in either the 11th or 12th century. The artist Basil, who painted the miniatures, signed the portrait of St. Simeon Stylites (fol. 151v), and added a prayer.

provenance.p: According to the only dated colophon (fol. 202v), the scribe Iohannes, who supplied the manuscript's missing text on paper, finished his work in the year 1465 (6973). An undated colophon in Arabic on the same folio is possibly that of a one-time owner. Its content was covered over by the addition of a piece of paper hinged to the leaf, which contains a transcription of the 15th century scribe's colophon. Undated notation and prayer (front pastedown, fol. 52v). University of Chicago Libraries bookplate (front pastedown).

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago in 1940 from Trini Kouzoutzakis who purchased the manuscript in Berat, Albania.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

msItem.summary: Synaxarion. John, weekday, Saturday, and Sunday Lections.
Synaxarion. Matthew, Saturday, and Sunday Lections.
msItem.note: Text of the paper leaf ends with the reading for Saturday, Week 16 after Pentecost, Matthew 24:34-44 (fol. 52r). The text on parchment, fol. 53r, begins with the reading for Sunday, Week 16 after Pentecost (Liturgy) Matthew 25:14-30. Lacking verse 14, it starts with 25:15 at, και απεδημησεν ευθεως.

msItem.summary: Synaxarion. Luke, Saturday, and Sunday Lections.
Synaxarion. Great Lent, Saturday and Sunday Lections.
Synaxarion. Palm Sunday, Holy Week, Monday through Thursday Lections.
Synaxarion. Twelve Lections of the Holy Passions.
Synaxarion. Good Friday and Holy Saturday Lections.

overview.p: Quarter-page miniatures number 4, and include portraits of the Evangelists Mark and Matthew, of St. Simeon Stylites the Elder and his mother the Venerable Martha, and of the Christ Child's Presentation in the temple.

minItem.minDesc: Evangelist, Mark: Portrait. Mark writing, seated on a cushioned platform.
Evangelist, Matthew: Portrait. Matthew stands holding book; hand of God blesses him (upper right).
Simeon Stylites: Scene, Visit from his Mother. Simeon seated on pillar; his mother the Venerable Martha stands below him at left.
minItem.colophon: Colophon of the artist Basil: Holy Symeon Stylites watch guard protect your servant Basil the abstemious surnamed Keberges for with affection he painted this icon of you. Prayer of Basil: Christ provide strength for my labors.

minItem.minDesc: Christ: Presentation. Before the temple altar, Simeon, at right, reaches for the Christ Child held by the Virgin Mary at left; Joseph stands behind her with an offering of doves.
